body.p:
Memphis, Sept. 2nd, 1865.
E. L. Van Winkle, Esqr.
Dear Sir:

I took the Amnesty oath under President Johnson's Proclamation & was thereby pardoned not being included in any class of the Exceptions. I have understood that Atty. Genl Speed has decided that the pardon from the President does not acquit from State charges.

I have taken the amnesty in good faith & mean to abide by it. I was a citizen of Tenn. at & during the war, and am now. I only went into Ky. together with the hosts of others under the order of commanding Confederate Generals -- & every act done there was as a regular soldier in discharge of a soldiers orders and duties -- I do not wish any further annoyance -- and will ask that you use your influence with the Gov. to extend to me for the state what President Johnson has for the U. S.

When I go up to Ky. to see my friends
I want to go as a gentleman free from all petty annoyances --
